comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Slightly indistinct and overly darkened copy of a picture of two Douglas A-3B Skywarrior equipped as aerial tankers, one refueling the other. A-3B Skywarrior 144627 Modex 5 A-3B Skywarrior 142659 Modex 2 Tail code ZB of VAH-4 'Fourrunners' Both these aircraft were tragically lost in different circumstances. A-3B Skywarrior 144627 Originally built as A3D-2. Accepted by US Navy June 1959. Became A-3B from 1962. Lost on March 8, 1967 during night mining sortie over North Vietnam (cause unknown) while operated from USS Kitty Hawk by VAH-4. Here is a full record of aircraft losses from CV-63 USS Kitty Hawk: www.ejection-history.org.uk/CARRIERS/USS_KITTY_HAWK/uss_k... 8 March 1967. USN. A 3B. 144627. Code ZB. Modex 5. VAH 4. North Vietnam. LCdr C O Crain; KIA. Lt (jg) G F Pawlish; KIA ATN2 Ronald E. Galvin: KIA Here is a record of the events of CV-63 USS Kitty Hawk: www.history.navy.mil/danfs/k4/kitty_hawk-ii.html “ 8 Mar 1967: Holly Green 5, an A-3B (BuNo 144627), LCDR Carroll O. Crain, Jr., LT(JG) George F. Pawlish, ATN2 Ronald E. Galvin, VAH-4 Det C, went down at sea en route to a mining mission over the Kien Qiang River, North Vietnam, 17º48’N, 106º38’E. Though due to “unknown causes,” Holly Green 5’s loss is considered combat-related, in all probability due to enemy ground fire.” In remembrance of Commander Carroll O. Crain, Jr., www.virtualwall.org/dc/CrainCO01a.htm asthevalleyturns.com/memorial.html ………………………………………………………………………………………………….. A-3B Skywarrior 142659 Originally built as A3D-2. Accepted by US Navy April 1959. Re-designated A-3B from 1962. Converted by NARF Alameda to KA-3B in June 1967, then to EKA-3B in Sept 1967. Re-configured back to KA-3B. Destroyed due to mishandled aborted take-off when with VAQ-308 from NAS Alameda. www.a3skywarrior.com/memorial/full_accident_date.htm VAQ 308 142659 10 Oct 1977 (9/10/1977) Oakland inner harbor immediate adjacent to boundary of NAS Alameda. Aborted take off at NAS Alameda. At 3500 ft. drag chute deployed and streamed. The tail hook was lowered. Tire marks extended for 4000'. Aircraft left runway and impacted harbor waters nose down. Pilot; LCDR John Bell RN: AME2 James Sullivan 1969 pictures of EKA-3B 142659 of VAQ-130, Modex 615, refueling A-4E Skyhawks, both with tail code NF from CV-31 USS Bon Homme Richard: a4skyhawk.org/5e/g151022/html/151131c1.htm a4skyhawk.org/5e/g151022/html/151131c2.htm Dated 8 August 1969. A record of EKA-3B 142659 aboard CVA-66 USS America for a period between April 10, & Dec.21, 1970: www.gonavy.jp/CVW9-NG1970.html Marked as Modex 617 when replaced another EKA-3B lost overboard on 4 July 1970. 142659 transferred to VAQ-129 DET.19 of CVW-21 aboard CVA-19 at beginning of December 1970. 26 December 1970 picture of EKA-3B 142659 with VAQ-129 as Modex 616 tail code NP of CVW-21 over NAF Atsugi, Japan: a3skywarriorforwhidbey.org/EKA-3B_142659_VAQ-129_DET_19_U... geta-o.maxs.jp/USMIL/A/A-3/EKA-3B/EKA-3B.htm geta-o.maxs.jp/USMIL/A/A-3/EKA-3B/Eka-3b(np616)142659-076... KA-3B 142659 of VAQ-308 "Griffins" at NAS Cecil Field in January 1976. (Photo: Paul Minert Collection via R. E. Kling) : www.aircraftprofiles.dk/?page_id=146&album=11&gal... www.aircraftprofiles.dk/wp-content/gallery/vaq-308-griffi... My respect to the crews of both aircraft, their families or friends. ………………………………………………………………………………………………….. During the Skywarrior production run, provision for airborne tanker equipment was incorporated on twenty A-3B airframes from serial number 142650. When the tanker package was retrofitted on earlier bombers as a permanent installation, the modified aircraft were then designated KA-3B. A-3B's could and did carry the tanker reel and hose/drogue unit prior to the 1967 official designation of KA-3B. The following passages from this web page titled 'Douglas A3D-2/A-3B Skywarrior' contains more relevant information: www.joebaugher.com/usattack/newa3_3.html "The next 20 A3D-2s (BuNos 142650/142665 and 144626/144629) were fitted with a midair refuelling probe on the port side of the aircraft that extended forward of the nose. Provision was made for the installation of a removable inflight refuelling and tanker package in the bomb bay, which included a hose reel unit and a large fuel tank. The aircraft was also equipped with Cambered Leading Edge (CLE) wings that incorporated inboard leading edge slats which increased the wing area from 779 to 812 square feet. The midair refuelling package, the flat panel nose radome, and the new dovetail fairing were progressively retrofitted to most of the early production A3D-2s." (credit to Professor Joe Baugher, Chicago, Illinois, USA)
